Scheduled-Asynchronous Distributed Algorithm
for Optimal Power Flow

Chin-Yao Chang â€ƒJorge CortÃ©s â€ƒSonia MartÃ­nez C.-Y. Chang, Jorge CortÃ©s, and Sonia MartÃ­nez are with the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of California, San Diego, CA, USA. Email: {chc433,cortes,soniamd}@ucsd.eduA preliminary version of this work appeared asÂ [1] at the 2017 American Control Conference.
Abstract

Optimal power flow (OPF) problems are non-convex and large-scale optimization problems with important applications in power networks. This paper proposes the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve a distributed semidefinite programming (SDP) formulation of the OPF problem. In this formulation, every agent seeks to solve a local optimization with its own cost function, physical constraints on its nodal power injection, voltage, and power flow of the lines it is connected to, and decision constraints on variables shared with neighbors to ensure consistency of the obtained solution. In the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm, every pair of connected nodes in the electrical network update their local variables in an alternating fashion. This strategy is asynchronous, in the sense that no clock synchronization is required, and relies on an orientation of the electrical network that prescribes the precise ordering of node updates. We establish the asymptotic convergence properties to the primal-dual optimizer when the orientation is acyclic. Given the dependence of the convergence rate on the network orientation, we also develop a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an orientation with diameter at most five for electrical networks with geometric degree distribution. Simulations illustrate our results on various IEEE bus test cases.

I Introduction

The optimal power flow (OPF) problem seeks to minimize the cost of electricity generation subject to voltage and power flow constraints. Finding a solution to the OPF problem is challenging due to its large-scale and non-convex nature and, therefore, it is typically solved off-line for centralized planning of power networks. However, recent technological advances involving the integration of renewable distributed energy resources introduce higher operational uncertainty in managing the electrical grid, motivating the need for real-time methods to solve OPF problems. Ideally, such methods should enjoy robustness against disturbances and tolerance against intermittent engagement of energy resources. An additional consideration further justifying the need for such methods is the increase of plug-and-play devices in distribution networks and the ensuing uncertain overall system configuration. Motivated by these considerations, this paper introduces a provably-correct distributed algorithm to solve a convexified OPF problem over a power network.

Literature review: Finding a global optimum of the OPF problem is challenging due to its non-convexity, so most existing algorithms only guarantee a local optimum, see e.g.,Â [2, 3, 4]. A commonly used approach in the literatureÂ [5, 6] to convexify the problem is the use of DC power flow equations. An alternative route for the convexification of the OPF problem is employing semi-definite programming (SDP). The workÂ [7] shows that the SDP convex relaxation on the OPF problem is exact for many networks, a fact that allows to find a global solution. Conditions on the exact convex relaxation have been further established inÂ [8, 9]. Several recent worksÂ [10, 11] further develop SDP-based algorithms for a near-global optimal solution for OPF problems where the SDP convex relaxation does not provide a feasible solution. Relatively few works consider solving the OPF problem in a distributed way. The paperÂ [12] proposes a distributed approach to the DC-OPF problem, where the electrical network is decomposed into several regions and each region solves its regional DC-OPF problem while iteratively matching its tie-line powers with the connected regions. The workÂ [13] considers an SDP-based convexification of the OPF problem and then proposes gradient-based primal-dual algorithm which displays fast convergence to the optimum in simulation studies. The algorithm design is limited to voltage magnitude constraints and linear objective functions and does not incorporate constraints on the active/reactive power. The workÂ [14] also considers a SDP-based relaxation of the OPF problem, partitions a so-called weakly-meshed network into several areas so that the â€œmacroâ€ graph describing the interconnected areas has a tree topology, and applies the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) to solve the distributed optimization associated with the macro graph. In general, gradient-based methods are amenable to asynchronous implementations, but have a rate of convergence Oâ€‹(logâ¡(n)/n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\log(n)/n) or slowerÂ [15]. In comparison, ADMM is faster with a Oâ€‹(1/n)ğ‘‚1ğ‘›O(1/n) convergence rateÂ [16], while requiring a synchronous implementation. Drawing connections with the increasing body of work on gossiping in network systemsÂ [17, 18, 19], our algorithm design prescribes pairwise updates between neighboring agents to avoid the requirement of clock synchronization while enjoying similar convergence properties as ADMM.

Statement of contributions: Our starting point for the algorithm design is the formulation of a distributed version of the OPF problem, where each bus (node) plays the role of an agent with computation and communication capabilities. Every node creates local copies of the voltage of the neighboring nodes which are physically connected to it. Each node poses an optimization with its local cost function, constraints of its nodal power injection and voltage, and constraints associated with the power flow of the connected lines. On top of those local physical constraints, every node also has equality constraints sharing to its neighbors to ensure that every copy of the variables coincides. We then consider the convexification of this distributed OPF formulation using semi-definite programming (SDP). Our first contribution is the synthesis of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve the distributed OPF formulation in a distributed way. In our design, every pair of connected buses solves their local optimization problem in an ADMM-like, alternating fashion. To establish the order of such alternating iterations across the network, every bus only updates its variables when all the neighboring buses have finished an update later than its last update. This logic does not require any clock synchronization between the agents, in contrast to ADMM. Our second contribution is the convergence analysis of the proposed scheduled-asynchronous algorithm. Under reasonable assumptions on the data defining the optimization problem and the requirement than the graph orientation is acyclic (to avoid â€œlockedâ€ situations where every bus is waiting for an update from at least one of its neighbors), we employ the LaSalle Invariance Principle to establish the convergence to the primal-dual solution. Given the dependence of the algorithm convergence on the orientation of the network graph, our third contribution concerns the optimal selection of this orientation. In fact, the time need for all agents to finish at least one update is directly related to the diameter of the oriented network graph, and hence it is desirable to minimize it. In general, finding an orientation that minimizes the diameter is equivalent to finding the chromatic number of the graph, which is NP-hard. We design a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an orientation with diameter at most five for electrical networks with geometric degree distribution. The distributed nature of this strategy makes it naturally robust to changes in the network topology. Simulations on various IEEE bus test cases of the combined graph coloring and scheduled-asynchronous algorithms illustrate the performance and robustness of the proposed design.

Organization: SectionÂ II presents basic concepts and notation. SectionÂ III introduces the OPF problem and its distributed formulation. SectionÂ IV presents the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm and analyzes its convergence properties. SectionÂ V introduces a distributed graph coloring algorithm to obtain an acyclic orientation of small diameter. SectionÂ VI illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in benchmark IEEE test cases. Finally, we gather our conclusions in SectionÂ VII.

II-B Graph Theory

We review basic notions of graph theory followingÂ [20]. A graph is a pair ğ’¢=(ğ’©,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’©â„°\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}), where ğ’©âŠ†â„•ğ’©â„•\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathbb{N}} is its set of vertices or nodes and â„°âŠ†ğ’©Ã—ğ’©â„°ğ’©ğ’©\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} is its set of edges. A loop is an edge that connects a vertex to itself. Two nodes i,kâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ’©i,k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} are connected if {i,k}âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The graph is undirected if {i,k}={k,i}âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ‘–â„°\{i,k\}=\{k,i\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The local neighborhood of a node kğ‘˜k in an undirected graph is ğ’©k:={lâˆˆğ’©|{l,k}âˆˆâ„°}âˆª{k}assignsubscriptğ’©ğ‘˜conditional-setğ‘™ğ’©ğ‘™ğ‘˜â„°ğ‘˜\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{k}:=\{l\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\;|\;\{l,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\}\cup\{k\}. The degree of a node kğ‘˜k is |ğ’©k|âˆ’1subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜1|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{k}|-1. In a directed graph, each pair of vertices in â„°â„°\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} is ordered such that the corresponding edge {i,k}ğ‘–ğ‘˜\{i,k\} has a direction, with iğ‘–i and kğ‘˜k distinguished as the tail and head nodes, respectively. Node iğ‘–i is a source (resp. sink) if it is the tail (resp. head) node of all the edges it belongs to. Node kğ‘˜k is an out-neighbor of node iğ‘–i if {i,k}âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The out-degree of node iğ‘–i is defined as |{kâˆˆğ’©|{i,k}âˆˆâ„°}|conditional-setğ‘˜ğ’©ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°|\{k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}|\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\}|. A path in a (directed or undirected) graph is a sequence of vertices such that any two consecutive nodes correspond to an edge of the graph. The length of a path is the number of its corresponding edges. The diameter of a graph is the maximum length of the shortest path connecting any two graph vertices in the graph. A cycle is a path whose first and last vertices are the same. A graph is acyclic if it contains no cycles. An orientation of an undirected graph is an assignment of exactly one direction to each of its edges. A graph orientation is acyclic if the resulting directed graph is acyclic. A graph is bipartite if the set of its vertices can be decomposed into two disjoint subsets such that, within each one, no two vertices are connected.

A simple graph is a graph with no loops nor multiple edges connecting any pair of two vertices. A planar graph is a graph that can be drawn on the plane in a way that its edges intersect only at their endpoints. A vertex-induced subgraph of ğ’¢=(ğ’©,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’©â„°\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}), written as ğ’¢sâ¡[ğ’©s]subscriptğ’¢ğ‘ subscriptğ’©ğ‘ \operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{s}[\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}], is a subgraph of ğ’¢ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} with the set of nodes ğ’©sâŠ†ğ’©subscriptğ’©ğ‘ ğ’©\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and set of edges â„°s=â„°âˆ©(ğ’©sÃ—ğ’©s)subscriptâ„°ğ‘ â„°subscriptğ’©ğ‘ subscriptğ’©ğ‘ \operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\cap(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}). A chordal graph is a graph that does not contain an induced cycle of length greater than four. Graph coloring consists of assigning a color to every node in the graph in such a way that any pair of connected nodes have different colors. The smallest number of colors needed to color a graph GğºG is called its chromatic number.

III Problem Formulation

This section introduces the problem of interest. We begin with a general formulation of the optimal power flow (OPF) problem over an electrical network. We then consider its convex relaxation and rewrite it as the combination of several smaller-scale interconnected convex subproblems. The resulting semidefinite programming (SDP) problem is the starting point for our distributed algorithm design.

The elimination of the rank constraint gives rise to the convex relaxation of the OPF problem.

Following the exposition inÂ [23], we next reformulate the OPF problem in a distributed way as follows. We start from the observation that every constraint except Eq.Â (6e) in (P1) is either related to the power injection at one bus or the voltage difference between connected buses. In addition, the power injection at one bus is only related to the voltage of the buses it is connected to. This property is embedded in the structure of the non-zero entries of the admittance matrix inÂ (3). As a consequence, we can rewrite the constraintsÂ (6a-6d) in terms of variables Wiâˆˆâ„‹Nisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–superscriptâ„‹subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W_{i}\in\mathcal{H}^{N_{i}} for all iâˆˆğ’©â¡ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\textbf{}, where Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i} is quadratic in the voltage variables corresponding to the local neighborhood ğ’©isubscriptğ’©ğ‘–\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i} in the electrical network graph, and Ni=|ğ’©i|subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’©ğ‘–N_{i}=|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i}|. where i^^ğ‘–\hat{i} refers the row (or column) of the matrix associated with busÂ iğ‘–i (note that Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i} and Wksubscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜W_{k} might have different dimensions). For chordal graphs, (P2) with the additional non-convex rank constraints, rankâ¡(Wi)=1ranksubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1\operatorname{rank}(W_{i})=1, âˆ€iâˆˆğ’©for-allğ‘–ğ’©\forall i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} is equivalent to (P1), seeÂ [24]. For general graphs, (P2) with the rank constraints does not necessarily give an optimal solution of (P1), but simulations indicateÂ [25] that (P2) has a low-rank solution whose value is close to the optimal value ofÂ (P1). In the rest of the paper, we assume that a unique optimal solution of (P2) exists, and we denote it as (Wğ’©â‹†,pâ‹†)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ‹†ğ’©superscriptğ‘â‹†(W^{\star}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}},p^{\star}).

Our objective in this paper is to design a distributed algorithm to solve (P2). We view each bus of the electrical network as a computing agent that can communicate with any other bus which is physically connected to. By distributed, we mean that each agent only requires information from neighboring buses that share their local variables to implement the algorithm. By solving the optimization problem, we mean that each bus eventually finds its own optimal allocation (not the optimal allocation for the whole electrical network). When considered collectively, the local optimal allocation with agreement on the shared variables yields the complete optimal solution.

IV The Scheduled-Asynchronous Algorithm

In this section, we first provide a design rationale for the scheduled-asynchronous distributed algorithm and then introduce it formally. We next proceed to characterize the algorithm convergence properties.

Using the continuity of the cost function, fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, having Î³it+superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¡\gamma_{i}^{t^{+}} sufficiently small for all iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} guarantees that the solution of AlgorithmÂ 1 is reasonably close to the optimum. The implementation of AlgorithmÂ 1 does not require synchronous updates between connected nodes, but involves a subtle ordering. We therefore term this strategy as the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm. Note that we use a global time index tğ‘¡t to time-stamp all the iterations in AlgorithmÂ 1 only for convenience. Every agent tracks the number of iterations locally, but in general does not know the global time index.

Remark IV.1.

(The orientation of the network graph must be acyclic). An important observation regarding the execution of AlgorithmÂ 1 is that the orientation ğ’¢^^ğ’¢\mathcal{\hat{G}} given to the electrical network graph must be free of cycles. Otherwise, given the meaning encoded by the orientation of each edge, a deadlock would occur: every node at the cycle would be waiting for the update from a neighboring node in the cycle. There are various ways in which the network can determine an acyclic orientation in a distributed way. For instance, if every node has a unique identity kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}, then, for each edge in â„°â„°\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}, one can designate the node with the smallest identity as the tail and the other node as the head. The resulting graph ğ’¢^^ğ’¢\mathcal{\hat{G}} is acyclicÂ [27]. We revisit this point in SectionÂ V below. â–¡â–¡\square

Remark IV.2.

(The scheduled-asynchronous algorithm as a single-valued map). The scheduled-asynchronous algorithm is, in general, a set-valued map due to the argmin operator inÂ (12). We illustrate the meaning of entries associated with a star network in an example with 555 nodes. For W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1}, its diagonal, first column, and first row elements are the entries associated with the star network centered at node one.

The analysis of the convergence properties of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm requires a careful consideration of the asynchronous updates of the nodes. Bounded Trajectories. We next justify that the trajectories of AlgorithmÂ 1 are bounded. According toÂ (A.39), the primal variable Wğ’©nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘›ğ’©W^{n}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}} always evolves in a compact set ğ’²ğ’²\operatorname{\mathcal{W}} and therefore is bounded. To show that the evolution of pnsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘›p^{n} is also bounded, we can reason by contradiction. If it were not, then the sequence Vâ€‹(Wn,pn)ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘Šğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘›V(W^{n},p^{n}) would go to infinity, and this would contradict the fact that the sublevel sets of Vğ‘‰V are invariant (which is as a consequence ofÂ (16)).

Remark IV.4.

(Convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 1). Characterizing the convergence rate of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm is challenging. The main reason for this is the fact that, given the particular characteristics of the design of AlgorithmÂ 1, the proof of TheoremÂ IV.3 identifies a LaSalle function, and not a Lyapunov one. This is in contrast with the convergence proof of ADMM, cf.,Â [16], where the availability of a Lyapunov function makes the convergence analysis and the rate characterization easier. If the network topology is bipartite, AlgorithmÂ 1 reduces to ADMM and hence shares the Oâ€‹(1/n)ğ‘‚1ğ‘›O(1/n) convergence rate established inÂ [16]. Based on this and our simulation results, we conjecture that AlgorithmÂ 1 also has Oâ€‹(1/n)ğ‘‚1ğ‘›O(1/n) convergence rate with a smaller constant. â–¡â–¡\square

V Directed Graph Design

Here, we first describe how the average time between two consecutive iterations under the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm for a node depends on the diameter of the orientation of the network graph. Motivated by this observation, we set out to find an acyclic orientation with minimal diameter in a distributed fashion. In general, finding such an orientation is equivalent to finding the chromatic number, which is NP-hard. However, exploiting the planar property of many power networks, we develop a distributed algorithm to determine an orientation with small diameter.

V-A Relationship Between Graph Coloring and Diameter

The updating sequence of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm depends on the orientation ğ’¢^=(ğ’©,â„°^)^ğ’¢ğ’©^â„°\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}). To see this, consider a path in ğ’¢^^ğ’¢\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}}, with iğ‘–i being the initial node and kğ‘˜k the end node. The update of kğ‘˜k requires that all other nodes in the path finish at least an update before it, which are processed in sequence starting from node iğ‘–i. The â€œwaiting timeâ€ of node kğ‘˜k associated to this path corresponds therefore to its length. Since the diameter of the orientation bounds the length of all the paths, this justifies finding an acyclic orientation which the smallest diameter. We formalize this problem next. Let Î©â€‹(ğ’¢)Î©ğ’¢\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) be the collection of all acyclic orientations of ğ’¢ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}. We denote by ğ’¢Ï‰subscriptğ’¢ğœ”\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{\omega} the directed graph corresponding to Ï‰âˆˆÎ©â€‹(ğ’¢)ğœ”Î©ğ’¢\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}). The problem we aim to solve is

Ï‰â‹†=argâ€‹minÏ‰âˆˆÎ©â€‹(ğ’¢)â¡(maxhâˆˆğ’«Ï‰â¡|h|),superscriptğœ”â‹†argsubscriptğœ”Î©ğ’¢subscriptâ„subscriptğ’«ğœ”â„\displaystyle\omega^{\star}=\text{arg}\min_{\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})}\big{(}\max_{h\in\mathcal{P}_{\omega}}|h|\big{)}, (32)

where ğ’«Ï‰subscriptğ’«ğœ”\mathcal{P}_{\omega} is the set of paths in ğ’¢Ï‰subscriptğ’¢ğœ”\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{\omega}, and |h|â„|h| is the length of the pathÂ hâ„h. The optimizationÂ (32) is directly related to the classical problem of finding the chromatic number ğ’³â¡(ğ’¢)ğ’³ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) of an undirected graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}Â [28]. In fact, one has

ğ’³â¡(ğ’¢)=1+minÏ‰âˆˆÎ©â€‹(ğ’¢)â¡(maxhâˆˆğ’«Ï‰â¡|h|).ğ’³ğ’¢1subscriptğœ”Î©ğ’¢subscriptâ„subscriptğ’«ğœ”â„\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})=1+\min_{\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})}\big{(}\max_{h\in\mathcal{P}_{\omega}}|h|\big{)}. (33)

In general, computing ğ’³â¡(ğ’¢)ğ’³ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) is NP-hard, see e.g.Â [29]. There are only approximate algorithms to find a solution, see for exampleÂ [30]. However, for planar graphs, the chromatic number is upper bounded by fourÂ [31] and, furthermore, there exists a quadratic-time algorithm to find a graph-coloring with four colors, cf.Â [32]. Fortunately, the following assumption holds for most electrical networks.

Assumption 1.

(Planar network topologyÂ [33]). Electrical networks have simple planar network topology.

If a centralized entity has information on the network topology, then the algorithm inÂ [32] can be run to assign a number (or color) to every agent. This procedure might be problematic in large-scale scenarios, specially in the presence of plug-and-play devices that easily change the network topology. This motivates our design of a distributed algorithm.

V-B Distributed Orientation Computation with Small Diameter

The following distributed algorithm fromÂ [34] finds an orientation of an arbitrary planar graph with diameter bounded by five (or equivalently ğ’³â¡(ğ’¢)â‰¤6ğ’³ğ’¢6\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})\leq 6):

  1. 1.

    find an acyclic orientation in a distributed way such that every node has out-degree at most five.

  2. 2.

    every node chooses a color that is different from all the out-neighboring nodes defined in step 1).

Note that any ordering of the colors induces an orientation of the graph, which is furthermore acyclic, cf. RemarkÂ IV.1. The algorithm above is simple to implement but may be conservative for electrical networks because, in general, the degree of most nodes is far less than six. In fact, empirical studiesÂ [35, 36] have shown that electrical networks have a degree distribution that follows the exponential distribution. Since the degree takes integer values, it is more appropriate to characterize the degree distribution with the geometric distribution â€“ the discrete analogy of the exponential distribution.

Assumption 2.

(Geometric degree distribution). In electrical networks, the number of nodes with degree at least d0âˆˆâ„•subscriptğ‘‘0â„•d_{0}\in\operatorname{\mathbb{N}} satisfies

Probâ€‹(d=d0)=Î»â€‹(1âˆ’Î»)d0,Probğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0ğœ†superscript1ğœ†subscriptğ‘‘0\displaystyle\text{Prob}(d=d_{0})=\lambda(1-\lambda)^{d_{0}}, (34)

with parameter 0â‰¤Î»â‰¤10ğœ†10\leq\lambda\leq 1.

Most nodes have small degree due toÂ (34). According toÂ [35, 37], the average degree of empirical electrical networks is between 222 and 333. Many electrical networks, as a result, have the chromatic number far less than six. For example, IEEE 14, 30 and 57 bus test cases have ğ’³â¡(ğ’¢)=3ğ’³ğ’¢3\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})=3. Therefore, it is conceivable that one can find an orientation with diameter less than five. Motivated by this observation, we modify the algorithm inÂ [34] to exploit the geometric degree distribution property.

We propose AlgorithmÂ 2 to find a preliminary orientation. The idea is to first try to find an orientation with the out-degree of all nodes no bigger than 2. If this is not possible, then the strategy searches instead for an orientation with one more out-degree. If necessary, this process is repeated until AlgorithmÂ 2 eventually finds an orientation where the out-degree of all nodes is at most five.

We next explain the pseudocode of AlgorithmÂ 2. Every node iğ‘–i starts with an initial number Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} such that Î·iâ‰ Î·ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta_{i}\neq\eta_{k}, for all {i,k}âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. These numbers induce an acyclic orientation by declaring that node iğ‘–i is a tail of {i,k}ğ‘–ğ‘˜\{i,k\} if Î·i<Î·ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta_{i}<\eta_{k}, cf. RemarkÂ IV.1. Under the algorithm, every node iğ‘–i recursively updates Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} if its current out-degree is bigger than or equal to a number hÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–\overline{h}_{i}, initially set to hÂ¯0=2superscriptÂ¯â„02\overline{h}^{0}=2, for allÂ iğ‘–i. The update of Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} follows a simple rule to choose a number bigger than Î·ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta_{k}, for all kâˆˆğ’©iğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ‘–k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i}. In this way, node iğ‘–i becomes a sink node with out-degree zero in the new induced orientation. Node iğ‘–i then sends Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} to all kâˆˆğ’©iğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ‘–k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i} for them to recompute their out-degree. If all nodes do not require any further update in their Î·ğœ‚\eta, AlgorithmÂ 2 converges to an orientation in which all nodes have an out-degree of at most two. If, instead, some nodes require an update for more than mÂ¯>1Â¯ğ‘š1\overline{m}>1 times, then the strategy has these nodes increase its hÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–\overline{h}_{i} by one (since an orientation with out-degree less than two might not exist). Any node iğ‘–i that again updates its variable mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m} times has hÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–\overline{h}_{i} increased in a similar way. The procedure repeats until every node stops updating.

The following result establishes the convergence properties of AlgorithmÂ 2.

Proposition V.1.

(Convergence of AlgorithmÂ 2). AlgorithmÂ 2 converges with hÂ¯iâ‰¤6subscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–6\overline{h}_{i}\leq 6 for all iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} in a finite number of iterations.

With the orientation induced by the Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} variables resulting from the algorithm, one can find a coloring of the graph with hÂ¯:=maxiâˆˆğ’©â¡hÂ¯iassignÂ¯â„subscriptğ‘–ğ’©subscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–\overline{h}:=\max_{i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}\overline{h}_{i} colors. In AlgorithmÂ 2, setting mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m} too small can be conservative because the strategy gives up too early in finding orientations with small diameter by rapidly increasing hÂ¯ksubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘˜\overline{h}_{k} toward six. Theorem V.2.

(On the degree of subgraphs and convergence of AlgorithmÂ 2). If hÂ¯i0=c0<6superscriptsubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘06\overline{h}_{i}^{0}=c_{0}<6, for all iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and mÂ¯=âˆÂ¯ğ‘š\overline{m}=\infty, then AlgorithmÂ 2 converges if and only if every vertex-induced subgraph of ğ’¢ğ’¢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} has at least one node with degree less than c0subscriptğ‘0c_{0}.

Otherwise, node iğ‘–i is in ğ’®1subscriptğ’®1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1}. Hence, once a stable node iâˆˆğ’®2ğ‘–subscriptğ’®2i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2} updates Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i}, its out-degree, |ğ’©Î·i|subscriptğ’©subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|, is at most hÂ¯iâˆ’1subscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–1\overline{h}_{i}-1 and the node will not update Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} again. We can reason with ğ’®3,ğ’®4,â‹¯,ğ’®ssubscriptğ’®3subscriptğ’®4â‹¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘ \operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{3},\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{4},\cdots,\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{s} in a similar way until âˆªÎ±=1,2,â‹¯,sğ’®Î±=ğ’©subscriptğ›¼12â‹¯ğ‘ subscriptğ’®ğ›¼ğ’©\cup_{\alpha=1,2,\cdots,s}\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} (note that s<âˆğ‘ s<\infty because N<âˆğ‘N<\infty) and conclude that AlgorithmÂ 2 converges in finite time.

Next, we show the implication from left to right. If there exists a vertex-induced subgraph with all nodes having degree at least c0subscriptğ‘0c_{0}, then we can show that at least one node in the subgraph updates Î·ğœ‚\eta infinitely often. Recall that every acyclic orientation has a source node. The source of the subgraph updates its Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} because |ğ’©Î·i|â‰¥c0subscriptğ’©subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğ‘0|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|\geq c_{0}. After this update, the orientation of the subgraph remains acyclic because it is induced by the values of the variablesÂ Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i}. As a consequence, at least one node of the subgraph becomes a source and makes an update. The sequence repeats for infinite times because there always exists one node in the subgraph with |ğ’©Î·i|â‰¥c0subscriptğ’©subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğ‘0|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|\geq c_{0}. Since the number of nodes is finite, there exists at least one node that updates Î·ğœ‚\eta infinitely often. As a consequence, AlgorithmÂ 2 does not converge. âˆ

TheoremÂ V.2 provides insight into the selection of mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m} in AlgorithmÂ 2. With the notation of the proof, if we set mÂ¯=âˆÂ¯ğ‘š\overline{m}=\infty and AlgorithmÂ 2 converges with hÂ¯i0=c0<6subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯â„0ğ‘–subscriptğ‘06\overline{h}^{0}_{i}=c_{0}<6, for all iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}, the nodes in ğ’®Î±subscriptğ’®ğ›¼\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha} update their variables at least the number of times that nodes in ğ’®Î²subscriptğ’®ğ›½\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\beta} do, for Î²<Î±ğ›½ğ›¼\beta<\alpha, because ğ’®Î±subscriptğ’®ğ›¼\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha} becomes â€œstableâ€ after ğ’®Î²subscriptğ’®ğ›½\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\beta} does. If, instead, we choose a finite mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m}, then only a subset of nodes of ğ’©ğ’©\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} keep their variable hÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘–\overline{h}_{i} non-increasing, while the remaining nodes are forced to increase it, resulting in a more conservative upper bound of their out-degrees. The number of updates required for the last node being stable highly depends on the network topology. If Î»ğœ†\lambda is large, then most nodes have degree one or two, and ğ’®1subscriptğ’®1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1} contains most nodes in ğ’©ğ’©\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. In this case, we can expect âˆªÎ±=1,â‹¯,sğ’®Î±=ğ’©subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯ğ‘ subscriptğ’®ğ›¼ğ’©\cup_{\alpha=1,\cdots,s}\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} with a small sğ‘ s, so selecting a small mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m} still provides a small hÂ¯Â¯â„\overline{h} with fast convergence time. Our experience shows that selecting mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\overline{m} around 101010 is sufficient to yield an optimal coloring for electrical networks. The number may increase for some large networks that involve thousands of nodes.

VI Simulations

Here, we validate the performance of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm over the six bus test cases inÂ [38], IEEE 14, 30, and 57 bus test cases. We first use AlgorithmsÂ 2-3 to find an acyclic orientation of each test case, cf. TableÂ I.

This results in orientations with diameter two for all test cases except the six bus test cases, with diameter three.

FigureÂ 2 shows the convergence of AlgorithmÂ 1 for the various test cases. The stopping criteria is Î³i<10âˆ’4subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–superscript104\gamma_{i}<10^{-4} for all iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. The horizontal axis in the plots is the global iteration number, not the iteration per bus (the number of iterations per bus is roughly the global iteration number divided by the diameter of the acyclic orientation).

TableÂ II and FigureÂ 2 show that the weighted selection of ÏğœŒ\rho, discussed in RemarkÂ IV.5, leads to a much faster convergence than the uniform Ïiâ€‹k=Ï0subscriptğœŒğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğœŒ0\rho_{ik}=\rho_{0}, for all {i,k}âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. We have also simulated the case with unreliable communication, where every link has a 10%percent1010\% probability of packet drop if the previous communication was successful. TableÂ II shows that the AlgorithmÂ 1 still converges, albeit requiring more iterations than the case with no packet drops. FigureÂ 3 illustrates the transient behavior for the packet drop case.

Finally, we evaluate the impact of the acyclic orientation in the algorithm convergence in FigureÂ 4. We simulate how AlgorithmÂ 1 converges for the IEEE 14 and 30 bus test cases with an arbitrarily chosen acyclic orientation instead of the one obtained from the execution of AlgorithmsÂ 2-3. Compared with FigureÂ 2(b)-(c), one can observe that the algorithm requires many more iterations to converge and that â€–râ€–normğ‘Ÿ\|r\| increases dramatically at several iterations. These abrupt changes can also be explained as the result of several long paths in the digraph. In fact, recall that every node in a path makes one iteration before transferring its update to the following node. Starting with one of the terminal nodes in a long path, the update propagates through many nodes before reaching the other terminal node for its next update, at which point it may introduce a big change on its decision variables resulting in a dramatic change on â€–râ€–normğ‘Ÿ\|r\|. Therefore, the selection of an acyclic orientation with small diameter has the added benefit, beyond reducing the average waiting time per iteration, of resulting in less abrupt changes in the algorithm execution.

VII Conclusions

We have designed the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve SDP convexified OPF problems in a distributed way. Under the proposed strategy, every pair of nodes connected in the electrical network update their local variables in an alternating fashion and the ordering of node updates is encoded by an orientation of the network. We have established the algorithm convergence to the optimizer when the orientation is acyclic and shown how, when the network is bipartite, the strategy corresponds to the ADMM scheme and has therefore Oâ€‹(1/n)ğ‘‚1ğ‘›O(1/n) convergence rate. The convergence result does not require strong convexity of the cost function, which makes it especially suitable in OPF applications. To improve the algorithm convergence rate, we have introduced a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an acyclic orientation with small diameter for networks with geometric degree distribution. Future work will explore the characterization of the convergence rate for general network topologies, the optimal selection of the algorithm parameters, and the formal analysis of the algorithm robustness properties observed in simulation.
